He may lose his home, and the strain on his family's health has been unbearable. The new cap of £50,000 may have prevented the college from taking action. I also welcome the fact that the cap will be index-linked.
The Bill causes the Tories many difficulties because it not only goes against their natural sense of injustice, but will add to their unpopularity. There is a generation—Thatcher' s children—who, come the next general election, will see huge differences between our policies on representation, fairness at work and the minimum wage and the bad old ways under the Tories. They will easily make a decision.
Before I came to the House, I worked with young people. Shortly before the election, a young lad told me that he had just been fired from a job packing oranges. He had worked for the company for six months and there had never been any concern about his work. I asked him why he was sacked and he replied, "I was talking to the person who was standing next to me. That's the way that we are treated." He had no expectation of being treated any other way, but he did not have any commitment to the company.
That young lad will have his first vote at the next election, as will millions of other young people, and what a stark contrast he will find between our policies and the bad old ways under the Tories. I, along with my hon. Friends, will certainly be reminding him of that—but, having listened to many speeches in the debate, I do not think that he will take too much reminding.

It is a privilege to take part in this debate. The key test of the Bill should be whether or not it improves industrial relations. One of the reasons that this country's economy has been so successful since 1979 is that we have had an increasingly liberal employment regime. One has only to consider countries with successful economies, such as the United States with its mobile and flexible labour laws, to understand the damage that the Bill could do.
If we look back to the circumstances that we inherited in 1979, we remember the bad old days of secondary picketing, flying pickets and the intimidation and even violence that went on during strikes. We can remember the results of those strikes, such as the closed-shop dispute at Grunwick and the dreadful pay disputes in 1975,
when Ford workers went on strike for a 50 per cent. pay rise and were awarded a 30 per cent. rise. That is the regime that we took over in 1979. A staggering 29 million working days were lost to strikes in that year. By 1997, only 235,000 days were lost to strikes. That was a result of the regime that we put in place during the 1980s and 1990s.
Would my hon. Friend like to hazard a guess as to how many members of the present Cabinet supported Baroness Thatcher's reforms to remedy the problems that he has just identified?

It is not difficult to guess that figure, because I doubt whether any Labour Member supported the Thatcher reforms.
My remarks are not political—I genuinely want there to be good industrial relations in this country. I totally oppose, as every hon. Member should be elected to this place to oppose, unnecessary burdens on employers, because only through entrepreneurship and success, especially of small businesses, will this country ultimately be successful as an economic power.
One of the great achievements of the Thatcher years was that we created 1 million extra small businesses employing 1 million extra people. I want there to be full employment, a labour force richly rewarded for their work and people with mobility who have proper skills and training. That is the economy that I want this country to have.
My fear is that we shall have an economy that is increasingly dirigiste, increasingly regulated and, increasingly taxed and that imposes increasing burdens on small businesses. Why, for example, does the Bill use the arbitrary figure of 20 workers above which the provisions will apply, ignoring all the pleas and representations made by the CBI that a more realistic level for small businesses would be 50 employees?
I sincerely hope, in a non-partisan way, that the Minister will consider that factor. I think that a business employing only 20 people will be saddled with a huge burden if it is forced to recognise the trade union membership of its entire work force, given the costs associated with employment law and other aspects of such recognition. Given that we want to encourage seedcorn businesses, surely it would be sensible to increase the number to a more realistic 50.

Should it not be emphasised that, although firms with 20 or fewer employees are excluded from the requirements relating to trade union recognition, no firm is excluded from the provisions of the parental leave directive, because of the Government's crass folly in signing up to the social chapter?

I entirely agree—and, as my time is limited, I shall say something about parental leave now.
Parental leave is difficult to define. How old will a child have to be, and what evidence will have to be produced, before leave can be claimed? It strikes me as folly for both parents to be eligible. I do not mind whether the father or the mother is eligible, but it seems unreasonable for both to be eligible at the same time.
The Bill has another worrying aspect. The increasing trend towards secondary legislation is creeping into all the Government's Bills. It is a bad trend and an undemocratic
trend: it means that regulations can be introduced through secondary legislation and need not be properly scrutinised and debated in the House. I think that law should be accurately drafted and introduced through primary legislation so that the House can scrutinise it. Under the last Finance Bill, for instance, regulations were introduced to provide for all the necessary preparation for the euro. I consider that to be an abuse of Parliament. This Bill, too, provides for increased secondary legislation.
The provision relating to the Central Arbitration Committee also worries me. We do not know what the committee's role will be, or how its membership will be composed. We do know—because clause 22 tells us—that the committee shall consist of members appointed by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of State cannot even trust those members to appoint their own chairman: he will make the appointment for them. That shows how little the Government trust democracy. The committee might actually be composed of independent people who are able to make up their own minds.
We know that the committee's members must be "experienced in industrial relations". Thank goodness for that. What would be the point of appointing people with experience of stamp collecting or some other irrelevant qualification? We would expect them to have proper qualifications. We also know that some members must have experience as employers. That, surely, is only right, in a Bill in which partnership has a role to play.
Time is limited, so I will finish my speech. I believe that this is the ultimate payback to the trade unions for all that they have donated to the Labour party between 1979 and now. How much has the payback been—£100 million or £150 million? I do not know; we can only guess and speculate. The Bill, however, is the ultimate prize. That is unfortunate, because I think that it will have a detrimental effect on unemployment. Already, about 18.5 million people are unemployed in Europe. Fortunately, the trend has fallen progressively in this country over the past two or three years. What a tragedy it would be if people became unemployed solely as a result of the Bill.
It is, I think, almost inevitable that employers on whom extra costs are imposed will become less competitive. When the far east begins to get its act together, it will produce some highly competitive electrical and chemical goods, and those industries will be able to undercut our firms, which will be shackled with European-type legislation. If we do not resist such legislation, Britain will sink further and further, and become less and less competitive. We shall drift back to the bad old days of 1979, with secondary picketing and flying pickets. I hope that the Government will have second thoughts and ameliorate the worst aspects of the Bill.

The hon. Member for Cotswold (Mr. Clifton-Brown) argues, with amazingly scant regard for the facts and figures associated with the Administration whom he supported, that the Bill will cause a catastrophic rise in unemployment. Two thirds of manufacturing capacity was destroyed by the previous Government, and one business went bust every three minutes.
Like many other hon. Members, I shall declare an interest. I am a member of MSF—the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union—but I also have experience of being a small employer and a large employer, in the profit sector and the not-for-profit sector. With that background, I know that many of the arguments that I have heard from Conservative Members are lazy, old-fashioned politics. That is as out of date in the Chamber as it is useless in the debate about how to go forward in industrial relations in a modem economy.
The tried and tested way of punishing people and of levelling down pay, skills and terms and conditions did not work. It caused strife and blight in communities. It is laughable for the Conservatives to position themselves as the pro-family party. Their industrial relations legislation had a disastrous effect on the people whom I represent and, indeed, on my family.
How can people plan a stable family environment when they have a zero-hours contract—when they turn up day after day, not knowing whether they will be paid for their work? How can there be a positive planning environment for a family without paid holidays? Those are the basic needs of families, which are the building blocks of our communities and society.
The family-friendly aspects of the Bill apply universally to all workers. Good employment will once again mean good family policies. The world of work and the world of home must work together. One cannot ignore the fact that, when a child is sick, that affects the family members who work—the mother or the father. Businesses that have good, flexible practices reap the rewards. The amount of sick leave taken by their employees decreases because of the greater flexibility and the greater honesty and loyalty of the work force.
Many of my hon. Friends have quoted case studies from their constituencies which showed that workers' loyalty and productivity increased if they were valued. We could all quote ad infinitum examples of the destructive effect of bad employment practices.
Various aspects of the Bill are worth highlighting. The agency clause is important. An agency representing workers in a competitive, high-skill, high-wage sector is entirely different from agencies that operate in constituencies such as mine. Such agencies have worked for years to negate employers' responsibilities for terms, conditions and basic minimum rights. That is wrong. I welcome the fact that some of the more honourable Opposition Members acknowledged that the denial of those rights shames all of us and is bad for the economy, for business and for society.
I welcome the provisions on the working terms for part-time workers. In my constituency, a lot of work is part-time and, by increasing the rights of part-time workers, we have enfranchised thousands of my constituents who previously did not think that legislation covered them. They would never have thought of going to their trade union, because they knew that they did not have any rights that could enfranchise them. Now they can go to their trade union and actively choose to be represented, because they have rights. That will change their outlook and enable them to participate more, and it will be wholly welcomed.
We have to get back to a more intelligent, balanced debate about the art of the achievable, and I firmly believe that the Bill is a start in terms of minimum standards in the workplace. It states the humane standards, which were eloquently set out by my hon. Friend the Member for Hull, West and Hessle (Mr. Johnson). We all know of the old lazy politics of the bad old days, of the left and the right. Neither was particularly useful to good business or to good employment practice or for workers' representation.
The good management of business is difficult. Some of us have been managers, and management is an underrated skill. It is said that people are promoted into management when they do not have management skills, but have been good at their job. We must realise that it is a shoddy excuse when a bad manager says that it is difficult to achieve something with a poor employee.
Training and investment, which are part of the Bill, will help employers to deal with issues of motivation, reskilling and directing their work force. Training and investment will not hinder that and they have never been provided for previously in legislation. On several levels, the Bill is good—not only for business, but for positive trade unionism. I plead with Conservative Members, as well as with commentators outside the House, to stop using the old reference points of, "Business good, trade unions bad". There is good and bad on both sides of the fence.
Trade unions have used the challenge of the legislative framework that they had to work within, and the representation that they give to their membership is second to none. In constituencies such as Rochdale, the good trade unions are gaining members hand over fist. Membership is thought to be a good insurance policy, because all the services that trade unions provide are considered to be a vital lifeline for lots of employees in fragmented satellite work forces.
We must continue to consider small businesses. I understand their plight, because the economy of my community is based on them, but it should not stop us trying to work out ways to overcome the problems that they have because of their unit of resource—one, two or three employees. We should federate those businesses, look at the supply chain in which they work and seek imaginative ways of encouraging them to adopt good practice, even though it may not be possible, through this legislative framework, to include them in that.
Many of the vulnerable workers who will be helped by the Bill, especially in constituencies such as Rochdale, are non-English speakers. They may be in low-skill, low-wage temporary work, but, if we are to enfranchise the total population with their rights under the Bill, we must consider using other languages within targeted communities to make sure that people such as the Asian women from Pakistan and Bangladesh whom I represent receive their rights as much as well-enfranchised English speakers.

I begin with two declarations. The first is of my interest as the employer of one full-time employee. The second is the fact that I am ever hopeful. In that context, I hope that the House will have the wisdom to accept our reasoned amendment, which was moved so elegantly and eloquently by my right hon. Friend the Member for Wokingham (Mr. Redwood).
My right hon. Friend shares, with many hon. Members on both sides of the House, my aspiration for good industrial relations based on voluntary agreement. He also shares my scepticism in respect of the Bill's central proposition, which is that partnership is best, or only, secured by coercion. We do not believe that to be true.
As my right hon. Friend said, the economy is teetering on the brink of recession, and it is against that background that the debate has taken place. Undoubtedly, manufacturing industry is already deep in recession with successive months of downturn in production. The prospects are no better for white collar occupations—tell that to people who work for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell or Barclaycard.
The Chancellor and the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry will have to do rather better in future than they have done with the windy banalities of their 10 productivity roadshows. Their rhetoric suggests to me that they have discovered a new grammar based entirely on adjectives, with the noun disappearing from sight. Even new Labour's newspeak cannot identify the assertion of a proposition with the reality of that proposition. It is time that Ministers came out of denial and came to terms with the fact that, in the Prime Minister's words—which will return to haunt him—hard choices sometimes have to be made.
The Bill has been designed explicitly to increase employee rights—even if they are coyly retitled "employment relations", whatever that means—and it cannot avoid increasing costs and hassle for businesses of all sizes. It does that precisely when the economy and business, which is the sole creator of wealth in this country, are already under great pressure.
My hon. Friends who contributed to the debate have spoken cogently of the difficulties that the Bill will cause employers and, ultimately, their employees. We shall explore those difficulties in greater depth in Committee. Labour Members have naturally been somewhat friendlier towards the Government's proposals, and they have made contributions based on their undoubted industrial knowledge. Given the different flavours—some of them old trade unionists and some of them new Labour—an internal debate seems to have taken place in the Labour party.
Is that so terrible?

Indeed, it is very welcome. Conservative Members share the Government's declared enthusiasm for the warm things such as partnership and productivity, but saying them is not achieving them. I ask Labour Members to consider that, because there is a real danger that the Government's stated intentions will backfire, and they may end up doing more harm than good. I need hardly remind Ministers of the danger of unintended consequences, given that they are grappling with the question whether au pairs qualify as employees for the purposes of the national minimum wage.
The Opposition want fair and practical legislation, and we approach the Bill in that spirit. I am afraid that the Government have contributed to the uncertainty about the impact of the Bill. Even for this Government, the structure of the Bill is more dependent than usual on subsequent regulations—for example, to prescribe the details of parental leave and what constitutes a domestic emergency.
There have been eight months of consultation. It seems to me that there will have to be another eight months of consultation before we know the answers.
It is clear that the Government are moving towards a much looser definition of parental leave than is required by the European directive—they are gold-plating it. My hon. Friends have drawn attention to Irish law, although we do not want to follow Irish law in providing for paid parental leave.
The Government have said that this is their final word on industrial relations matters. That is rather reminiscent of the eerie phrase from pre-war Germany that this was positively their last territorial claim.
Will Ministers here and now rule out any extension of parental leave to include a requirement of payment by hard-pressed employers—yes or no? We shall not know about that and so many other matters until the regulations are made. I am inclined to suggest that we should retitle the Bill "Employment Relations (Further Details to Follow)".
Some things, however, are clear enough. This is old Labour's finest hour in the shape of the Minister of State enjoying it. New Labour is paying its grudging homage to the past. We are beginning to understand that, during Labour's frustrating years in opposition, the unions shelled out more than £100 million at today's prices to the Labour party. That investment led to manifesto commitments, particularly and notoriously on union recognition. Even now, damaging as they are, the Bill's provisions fall sadly short of the TUC's clear intention. I found it fascinating that so many Labour Members metaphorically left their gloves on the table for future challenges and extensions to the legislation.
Of course, the provisions are still too difficult for the CBI and other representatives of industry, even though the CBI joined in the haggle that preceded the famous treaty negotiated on 17 December by the right hon. Member for Hartlepool (Mr. Mandelson), after which he departed the scene. However, the CBI, as ever in measured terms, concluded: Getting the detail of the Bill's provisions and its implementation right is critical to minimising the negative impact on business. We need to consider that point rather carefully.

Much of the debate has focused on the Bill's negative impact on businesses. Does my hon. Friend think that it would have been a good idea had the Bill contained some provisions that were positive to business, such as providing employment or helping to increase profitability in some way?

Precisely. It is quite clear that the CBI thinks that the Bill's overall impact will be negative.
The Institute of Directors has been even blunter. It concluded: The Bill is entirely inconsistent with its objective of creating a competitive economy. These measures will sap the competitiveness of British firms. And so they will. [HON. MEMBERS: "They will not"] It is interesting to hear the barracking comments from Labour Members, but it is certainly the view of the employers' side of British industry that they will.
I ask the Government to provide a simple litmus test. In the terms of my hon. Friend the Member for Cotswold (Mr. Clifton-Brown), does the Bill contain a single
measure that reduces the burdens on employers and businesses? The gestation period of the Bill has had three successive Secretaries of State and, until now, it has never been clear whether they would jump left or right, but the Bill is left hand down all the way.
I now turn to our specific points of concern, starting with trade union recognition. Ministers know that the last time it was enforced, from 1975 until the fall of the Labour Government—much contributing to it—coincided with the virtual collapse of the British economy, and that disputes about recognition helped to sour the industrial climate. This time, some hurdles may cause resentment among the unions, but the CBI will not lie down under the proposal for automatic recognition when 50 per cent. of the relevant bargaining unit are in membership. That will have to be argued. Therefore, a great deal hangs on the performance of the Central Arbitration Committee. Previously almost the most self-effacing quango in the land, it now takes centre stage as it has to handle such important questions. It must have clear guidelines if it is not to spend its entire life in the tangles of judicial review. One of my major concerns is that this is a Bill for employment lawyers rather than for employment.
In respect of individual employment rights, I concede that, at least in this respect, the Government have listened to reason by changing their original proposals and retaining a cap on unfair dismissal claims, although it has increased fourfold to £50,000.
I should add—parenthetically, to be nice to the Minister of State, for once—that I am grateful to the Minister for embodying my suggestion of using algorithms, or logical trees, in his explanatory notes, to take people through how they should respond to claims for recognition. [Interruption.] I note what the Minister says about his own proposals.
We should recognise that, in at least two respects, the fourfold increase in the limit must tip the balance in favour of going to a tribunal. The first effect will be felt in claims of wrongful dismissal under contract. Through the notice period, such claims are currently limited to about £12,500, whereas this increase will provide for claims up to £50,000. Secondly, the increase will simply raise the stakes—the opportunity—of hitting the jackpot as against doing nothing at all.
In other words, the provision will pay employees—as they will be so advised—to have a punt in the tribunal. I foresee that that in itself, if it does nothing else, is likely to put a heavy strain on tribunals, which are already fully loaded. The strain is almost wholly unacknowledged in the Government's regulatory impact assessment, which suggests an impact, on unchanged claim numbers, of £1.8 million—confirming my suspicion, as ever, that regulatory impact assessments are a refined work of fiction.
Finally, I should deal with the Bill's family-friendly package. Ministers forgot about their debts to the unions when launching the legislation. They told the press that everything in the Bill was about the family, as a means of taking eyes off the ball of the much more controversial issue of recognition rights. The Opposition are not against the family—in case Government Members ever thought that we were.
The regulatory impact, even in the Government's own terms, on families is admitted to be very far from trivial, at about £29 million for parental leave, and another £15.8 million—a spuriously precise figure—for extensions of maternity leave. Of course, the parental leave provision takes no account of the cost if "domestic emergencies" are subsequently defined, as I suspect they will be, as whatever the employee wants them to be.
As the hon. Member for Eastleigh (Mr. Chidgey) said in his thoughtful speech, it would be interesting to try to define "domestic emergency" and to tell employees that they can have so many hours a year to deal with them. If we were to define such emergencies, they would become an entitlement and not an accidental necessity. That is before—I hope that the Minister will deal with the matter—any suggestion that the Government might extend the provisions to include paid leave.
All that omits the simple reality that—as my hon. Friend the Member for Beaconsfield (Mr. Grieve) said—for a small employer, loss of a key worker for three months, even if the leave were unpaid, could literally wreck a small business. Moreover, the costs that are so lightly imposed by the Bill fall on top of the burdens of regulation and record keeping already imposed by the national minimum wage and the working time directive. Over the period of a Parliament, those two measures alone are calculated to add about £15 billion to business costs in back-door regulatory tax, even before considering the front-door, straightforward business tax increases which amount to £25 billion. Faced with such burdens, small businesses will not expand employment. Many of them will not take the first step of taking on an employee.
You, Mr. Deputy Speaker, may ponder the purpose of the Bill. Although Ministers and Government Back Benchers have failed to concede it, Opposition Members know that, during the previous Government's period in office, the British economy flourished. For some months after the general election, it has continued to flourish, as part of the golden economic legacy bequeathed by us to Labour. As that legacy is now squandered in higher taxes, higher spending and greater regulation, we know that British business now faces the mother of all struggles—to stay internationally competitive.
One part of our legacy has remained largely untouched until now—our new settlement in employment law, created over a long period and not without difficulties. By 1994, that settlement had resulted in the number of days lost to strikes falling to 1 per cent. of its peak. There are some worrying signs, particularly in the public sector, that the numbers may be picking up.
Under any Government, employment law is a network of rights and responsibilities. We believe that the balance that we struck was broadly fair. There were some bad employers and some bad employees, and good practice was not always universal. However, the balance was about right, as the facts show.
We approach the Government's proposals with heavy scepticism, because we know where they come from and the constituency that they are designed to satisfy. We believe in certain simple concepts. Businesses create jobs and wealth. Entrepreneurs take risks in the face of uncertainty and open up new markets. Governments should not and must not hinder them. [HON. MEMBERS: "What about employees?"] I am interested that Labour Members should say that. I have repeated the words used
by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry last week at the Mansion house. It is clear that some of his hon. Friends were not invited to listen to him.
We fear that the detailed proposals in the Bill will not be in place of strife, in Barbara Castle's famous phrase, but will open up a place for strife. They will disturb a delicate balance of rights and responsibilities. The key is whether the proposals help business, and we shall test them against that criterion in Committee. They will then be subjected to the even greater test of events. In that spirit, I commend the reasoned amendment to the House.

speech.speakername: The Minister of State, Department of Trade and Industry (Mr. Ian McCartney)
speech.p:
We have had an interesting debate. I thank the 12 Labour Members who have contributed. We have seen commitment from all parts of the United Kingdom to partnership in the workplace, setting out new opportunities for employers and employees to work together. We are introducing a new settlement in employment relationships and a new environment for companies to flourish with commitment from the work force and a commitment back to the work force by employers.
It has been a disappointing debate for the Opposition. The Scottish Nationalists did not even turn up to give their support to workers from Scotland. They turned their backs on Scottish workers and gave a smack in the face to Scottish businesses, who support the Government's principles of partnership in the workplace to develop the Scottish economy and make it more competitive.
rose—

The hon. Gentleman is pleading with me to give him an opportunity. I have sat here for hour after hour. I do not know where he was, but he certainly was not in here supporting Scottish workers or Scottish businesses. That says a lot about him.
The Conservatives gave a pretty pathetic showing. They could not even muster enough speakers to put their tired old story to the House and the British people. We had to have Labour Member after Labour Member because there were no Conservatives left to speak in support of the right hon. Member for Wokingham (Mr. Redwood). In 12 years in the House, I have never known a Front-Bench spokesperson of any party to have so little support from his Back Benchers. [HON. MEMBERS: "Or his leader."] I shall come to his leader in a moment.
I welcome my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State to our first debate together in government. He has said that he is an outrider for new Labour's juggernaut. I wish him well in that position and I give him the commitment that I ride shotgun for that juggernaut. Anyone attempting to upset my right hon. Friend will have to deal with me first. I am looking forward to reuniting the team that we had before the election, when we worked together on the Jobseekers Act 1995 and a range of other measures that the Tory Government brought in. We will work well together to ensure that the Bill becomes a reality for millions of British workers.
There is a real difference of approach between the Conservatives and the Government, embodied not just in the Bill, but in the speeches and the eloquence of my right
hon. and hon. Friends, and the tatty—almost disgraceful—way in which some Tory Members threw aside any concept of partnership, minimum standards or the capacity for employers and workers to work together to make their business successful, so that workers and employers benefit from the fruits of that success.
Listening to the Conservatives, one would think that history commenced on 2 May 1997. Let us remember what the Government had to pick up. The previous Government opted out of Europe, leaving industry totally isolated and confused about whether it should comply with directives. They squandered millions of pounds of taxpayers' money on defending Tory ineptitude in the European courts. Every three minutes of every working day, a company went bust under the Tories. To make sure that they stayed bust, the Tories piled on an avalanche of 45,000 regulations on business. Tory Industry Ministers had a phrase, "Kill them and bury them". That was the demented policy of Tory Industry Ministers.
There were 45,000 regulations on business, and two thirds of Britain's manufacturing economy was decimated by the Tories—and they come here and say that they are on the side of business. They have been on nobody's side but their own. No wonder, at the last election, managers and workers alike united across Britain to get rid of the Tories and their aging and dogmatic approach to business and employment relations.
The Tories are uninterested in social partnership. Why bother, when a hire-and-fire culture pervades their party from top to bottom? Remember the hapless Viscount Cranborne? He was in a job for four centuries—[Interruption.] However, his managing director summarily dismissed him—sacked him—without even minimum consultation. There was no written warning, no grievance procedure and no appeal.
Viscount Cranborne is not the only person in the Houses of Parliament who has a lineage in parliamentary activity. My father, who is 80 this year, made his maiden speech in this House on 14 December 1970, opposing the Conservatives' Industrial Relations Bill. I am sure that he is listening to the debate this evening, and I wish to quote what he said nearly 30 years ago about the Tories and their view of industrial relations. It is quite illuminating. I will just use the favourable parts, as he was a bit of an old trade unionist. [HON. MEMBERS: "Oh!] I knew that that would get Tory Members going. My father said: Trade unions prefer to see a continued era of peaceful negotiation in industry, where trade unions are free to bargain for their members, and a truly free society where they can function on behalf of their members."—[Official Report, 14 December 1970; Vol. 808, c. 1021.] What my father said then about partnership and co-operation in a workplace where people wanted unions to represent them effectively was true 30 years ago, and it is true this evening. I am pleased that my father has stayed with us all this time, as we get back to the position where every worker in Britain—full-time, part-time, temporary, casual or agency—will be treated with dignity in a flexible labour market.
Not only are the Conservatives committed to hire and fire, but they also now practise age discrimination in a big way. Two weeks ago, Opposition Front Benchers were told that they were too long in the tooth, and they were threatened with the sack. The right hon. Member for Wokingham, seemingly, is not up to it. He was told that
he was a forlorn figure. The Daily Telegraph—the house magazine of the Conservative party—said that a slaughter of the old guard was to take place. No one, but no one, was impressed with him, and each time he got up to speak he lost the party even more support.
I used to be called D. C. M. McCartney—"Don't come back on Monday". I am devastated by the fact that the right hon. Member for Wokingham looks like inheriting that title. I feel a duty to advise him that he has some rights under the Bill and that it may protect him. He can have a fair hearing, the right to be properly represented and the right to be accompanied at grievance and disciplinary proceedings; and he should not be subject to a campaign of victimisation by his line manager. I hope that Wee Willie Winkie is listening to this.
I will be happy to assist the right hon. Gentleman, because he is too valuable an asset for the Labour party to lose. He is doing far too bad a job to be sacked. If, in the next few weeks, I can rush up anything to assist him, he should have a word in my ear and I will see what I can do. I am all in favour of all-party support and co-operation when it comes to people's employment rights. [Interruption.] I see that another hon. Gentleman wants to talk to me.

I am grateful to the Minister. He is trying to present the Bill as a family-friendly policy. If any of my right hon. and hon. Friends wanted to spend more time with their family, would he not be seeking to encourage them rather than taking them through a grievance procedure? He may have it a bit wrong, but of course we want them all to stay here and argue against the Bill.

It would probably be best for the British economy if they all spent more time with their family. While we are on the subject, I should like to say that I am the youngest grandfather in the House of Commons, with seven grandchildren, who are known in the family as the flying pickets.
There is a contrast between the Conservative party and the Government. The Conservatives argue on behalf of the few, and we are the Government of the many. We want to work with business and unions, not to impose ideology on them. That is why we set up the Low Pay Commission, with representatives of large and small employers as well as unions, to advise us on the level of the national minimum wage. That has been a successful example of partnership at work.
We took a similar approach on fairness at work. Soon after the general election, my right hon. Friend the Prime Minister asked the CBI and the TUC to narrow their differences on trade union recognition. The talks culminated in the constructive joint statement of December 1997, which formed the basis for the proposals on recognition and fairness at work in the White Paper that we published last May.
We are building a culture of partnership at national level to promote partnership at the level of the individual enterprise. We are taking time to consult, to listen and to involve the employers and the unions in the formulation of the legal framework for minimum standards in the workplace.
The best employers are already on board, involving and consulting their employees, through unions, works committees, staff councils, electronic media, quality circles, team briefings and a myriad of other channels. The best employers offer good conditions and excellent training and they reap the rewards of that investment: they get the best staff who stay with the business and give it their commitment and loyalty.
Who is right? Tesco or the right hon. Member for Wokingham; Blue Circle or the right hon. Gentleman; Hyder or the right hon. Gentleman; or the Co-op bank or the right hon. Gentleman? I believe that it is 4:0 to business. The right hon. Gentleman has a worse record than Glen Hoddle. I cannot help wondering what he was in a previous life. Perhaps he was Glen Hoddle.
Let me help the right hon. Gentleman and his colleagues. Partnership means the need to recognise and value the central role of the work force in any business, both financially and through day-to-day recognition of their contribution. Everyone must be encouraged to contribute to the success of the whole organisation. It also means the need for a common understanding of the business's aims and goals and for an agreed work culture.
Employers need to have a strategy for developing their employees, and not only the highly skilled or the high fliers. Workers must be encouraged to identify and enhance their skills in the enterprise and challenged to ensure that there is no waste of talent, and—crucially—there must be an inclusive relationship between employers and employee representatives. The critical difference between the Government and the Opposition is that we believe in partnership and want it to work. That is what the Bill is about.
Modern companies know that to succeed in the world economy there must be a contribution from staff. I give the House the example of two companies that recently have recognised trade unions for the first time. Hays Clinical Services stated: We are a modern, thinking company who see good industrial relations as vital to our success. The Gap Employment Agency said: The agreement works to both of our advantages. The union plays a role in negotiations and gets new members, while the company gets to keep staff for longer in a market with a traditionally high turnover. Everyone deserves to be treated decently and respected at work. The Bill is designed to achieve that. Much has been said in the debate about the costs of the Bill, about the way in which it is drafted and about the need not to impose unnecessary burdens on business. We have gone one better: employers and employees will benefit enormously from greater participation in the labour market, reduced staff turnover and a climate of greater commitment and trust in the workplace.
I know of a significant employer that reported that one of its core businesses had a staff turnover rate of up to 100 per cent. a year. Taking into account both growth and turnover, the company has to recruit 50,000 people a year just to stand still. That involves an astronomical cost for training and recruitment of around £85 million to £100 million a year, or about £1,750 per recruit. The company never gets a return on that investment, and that is why it is changing culture: it now recognises the minimum wage, trade unions and the need for partnership in the workplace. Partnership reduces the costs that employers bear as a result of bad practice.
The CBI tells us that £25 billion a year is lost to British industry through unregulated absenteeism. The Government's proposals will give people employment rights. It will also give employers the security to change the bad culture of unregulated absenteeism in the workplace, and they will therefore benefit hugely from the reduction in those terrible on-costs.
Various hon. Members asked questions earlier. Because of the time, I shall deal with those questions in Committee, or answer them by letter.
This is a proud day for the Government. Before the election, we made a number of pledges with regard to employment. We pledged to introduce a national minimum wage—done. We pledged to introduce the working time directive and holiday pay—done. We pledged to restore trade union rights at GCHQ, to introduce a new deal and to adopt the social chapter—all done. Now we are about to put in place the last major piece of the framework of reforms that will create a fairer and more modern labour market in Britain. The Bill honours our manifesto commitments on partnership in industry, and on rights and responsibilities in the workplace. It honours our commitments to strengthen family life.
Conservative Members have shown their disdain for the Government's programme for social partnership and for a renaissance in employment relations. The Opposition tabled an unreasoned amendment to the Bill, and their performance this evening has been lamentable. It raises one important question that they can dodge no longer. When the Opposition go into the next election, will they pledge to scrap the minimum wage? Will they remove rest breaks from workers who work for more than six hours a day? Will they abolish paid holidays for more than 2 million workers? Will they increase the period for unfair dismissal from one year to two? Will they scrap full-time rights for part-time workers, and stop time off for family emergencies? Will they cut maternity pay and maternity leave? All those pledges would be the consequence of their vote against the Bill this evening. The Opposition will not be allowed to wriggle.
I have waited all my working life to stand here and present this Bill to the House. I am proud to recommend it. I ask all hon. Members to support the Bill, British industry and millions of British employees.
Question put, That the amendment be made:—
The House divided: Ayes 135, Noes 395.

I am grateful to my colleagues for giving me such a warm send-off on my debate, although start-up might be a more appropriate term.
Let me start with a quotation: Patients charter offers Hobson's choice on mixed-sex wards. Government not even attempting to collect figures on patients denied beds in single-sex wards. Those are not my words, or those of any Conservative Member, but the words of the then shadow Secretary of State for Health, the right hon. Member for Islington, South and Finsbury (Mr. Smith), in a Labour party press release dated 20 November 1996. At the outset, I state that I am not, and have never held myself out to be, a medical expert—[Interruption.]
On a point of order, Mr. Deputy Speaker. May we have some order in the Chamber, so that we can listen to this important debate?
That is a matter for the occupant of the Chair to decide.

Thank you, Mr. Deputy Speaker.
I have come to the topic by a gradual process, though my involvement with people who have experience as professionals, as designers of mental health hospitals and units, as psychiatric experts and even as users of psychiatric services. I hope to explain why I felt it necessary to apply for this debate, by taking hon. Members through the process of the problem's gradual emergence in my awareness.
I return to the position in November 1996, when the Labour party was, rightly, protesting about the continuing problem of mixed-sex wards. I shall quote the right hon. Member for Islington, South and Finsbury further, because I totally agree with him. He said: The last Patients' Charter…said that patients could expect single-sex washing and toilet facilities; and that their wishes to be treated in single-sex wards 'will be respected wherever possible'. Note the words "and that", for they mean that it is not enough to give patients single-sex washing and toilet facilities and then to say that single-sex wards have been achieved. As the right hon. Gentleman went on to say: These two promises sound good on paper. But a report from the Patients' Association yesterday revealed that segregated washing and toilet facilities are far from being the norm; while patients all over the country commonly report that if they do express a preference to be treated in a single-sex ward, as the Charter encourages them to do, they are suddenly told that in fact their wait for treatment will be far longer as a result.
Let us look at the relevant section of the patients charter, which states: You have the right to be told before you go into hospital whether it is planned to care for you in a mixed ward for men and women. (It may not be possible to tell you this if you are admitted to hospital in an emergency.) In all cases, you can expect single washing and toilet facilities. If you would prefer to be cared for in single sex accommodation (either a single sex ward or 'bay' area within a larger ward which offers equal privacy) your wish will be respected wherever possible. There may be some cases, particularly emergencies, where a hospital cannot provide single sex accommodation. Labour was saying that that was a dead letter.
Does my hon. Friend remember that the Labour party manifesto said that it would take steps to abolish mixed-sex wards in the NHS? What has happened to that commitment?

I shall explain the developments. I am happy to acknowledge that some steps in that direction have been taken, but by no means enough has been done. I am concerned that, having taken a few steps in the right direction, which the manifesto commitment outlined, the Government are almost trying to say that the battle is won, the deed is done, the problem is solved. That is not so. Since I first took an interest in this subject some months ago, some worrying developments have made me realise the need to bring the matter more closely to the House's attention.
I remind the House that, on 12 December 1997, I proposed that the provision of single-sex ward areas be made a statutory commitment under the Mental Health (Amendment) Bill, which I moved after being fortunate enough to draw second place in the ballot for private Members' Bills. Sadly, the Government saw fit to amass a combination of Back Benchers and Front Benchers to waste five hours of parliamentary time and talk out the Bill.
Subsequently, there have been some more encouraging developments. In particular, I was tipped off about a development of a mixed-sex ward in a new psychiatric unit at Charing Cross hospital. I raised the issue with the Secretary of State, who gave a characteristically forthright response. He said, "It's news to me if any new mixed-sex wards are being constructed, and if they are, I will put a stop to it." As far as I can see, in this case, he did so.
At that point, the plot began to thicken. As a result of the Secretary of State rightly instructing Charing Cross hospital to revise its plans to create a new mixed-sex ward, the Goodmayes hospital—which was concerned that its proposals for its psychiatric unit would fall foul of the Secretary of State's determination to abolish mixed-sex wards—wrote to the NHS executive.

Does my hon. Friend agree that, in view of the express determination of the Secretary of State to end mixed-sex wards in psychiatric hospitals, it is very odd and surprising that the recently published mental health code of practice makes no reference to such a management objective?

I agree with my hon. Friend; indeed, I am about to explain why I think that may be. I much welcomed his reference to this omission in the code, when he considered it in Committee in January.
The Goodmayes hospital received a reply on 3 August 1998 from a lady called Judith Guest of the patients charter unit at NHS executive headquarters. It was sent to the consultant psychiatrist and clinical director of Goodmayes hospital, Mr. Andrew Margo, and said: Patients have a right to feel safe in hospital and it is recognised that there are special circumstances in mental health wards that have to be addressed to make patients feel secure. There should be separate sleeping and washing areas for men and women and those should be accessible to people when needed and suitable arrangements put in place to ensure that the area is safe. But completely segregating services would not be acceptable, as there are good clinical reasons to provide an environment in hospitals which, as closely as it can, prepares people for their return to their own accommodation". I am very concerned about that advice. Indeed, I have raised it in correspondence with and questions to the Secretary of State. Nor will it come as any surprise to the Under-Secretary, because I have done my level best to inform his office of my entire line of argument, in the hope that that would assist him in addressing specifically the points which concern me so much.

In considering what would be the norm in the community, under what circumstances can my hon. Friend imagine, for example, that women would find it the norm to have men whom they did not know in the same sleeping accommodation, and vice versa?

I am most grateful to my hon. Friend, as I am always am when she brings the searchlight of her intellect and her specialised knowledge to bear on these topics. She anticipates a point that I intended to make later, but I shall deal with it now because it is precisely what the group of users from the Maudsley hospital has emphasised to me in my two meetings with its members.
I take the opportunity to pay tribute to Jolie Goodman, Cath Collins, Lynne Clayton and Denise McKenna for the campaign that they have been running. They have collected a number of deeply worrying examples of what is entailed for a woman who finds herself an in-patient on an acute ward. First, they contrast two quotations to make the point that my hon. Friend has just emphasised. They quote a pilot wing manager from the Charing Cross development as saying: Sexual harassment is a fact of life in mental health wards…We feel that single-sex services themselves are not suitable here because we're trying to create a normal environment. The campaigners' response states: Mixed wards don't reflect a 'normal' society. They are full of a completely mixed bag of strangers in extreme distress who are forced to live in intimate circumstances with each other. We can all anticipate the extreme examples of abuse that might occur in such an artificial environment. I shall give only two examples that the campaign group has drawn to my attention. These are the experiences of people who have written to the group. The first concerns a female user who, in 1998, wrote: In 1995 I was a patient in"— I shall not name the hospital— and a woman on my ward was raped by a male patient who followed her into the female bathroom. I interject that all too often what is lacking is a proper definition of what is meant by a ward. The term "bay" is particularly misleading because it refers to corridors:
a male corridor opens off in one direction and a female corridor opens off in the other, but there is nothing apart from the vigilance of the staff to stop people going from one to the other.
The second example concerns a 17-year-old woman who, in 1998, wrote: I, too, have been sexually assaulted by two male patients on my ward in July of this year. This experience was so traumatic and dreadful that it stopped any progress I was making for several months. As I said, we could all imagine those extreme cases, and I had already thought of what might be entailed by those terrible circumstances; but what came as a revelation to me in the first-hand testimonies of the campaign group were the examples of more everyday occurrences with which female in-patients have to contend. I make no apology for reading out one or two that some people might find rather disgusting. The first states: On entering the games room, a female patient tripped over the legs of a male patient who was lying flat on his back on the floor masturbating. When she complained to a nurse, she was told, 'He's very ill, you know,' and nothing was done. The funny thing—funny peculiar or funny ironic, but not funny in any other sense—is that that patient was ill, and indeed it was not his fault, but he should not have been where she could stumble across him in that way, or vice versa.
Another example concerns a woman who found herself surrounded by half-dressed men asking whether she wanted a boy friend as she queued for breakfast. It has been explained to me that queueing is a key part of life as an in-patient. One queues for meals and one queues for medication. What does a female do if she is being groped or interfered with in a queue? What does she do if someone starts to bully her for her food or benefits? Another example concerns a frail lady who was bullied by a young male patient into handing him her benefit money.
Then there are the cases caused by proximity and geography. The men's toilets are sometimes at the beginning of the corridor leading to the dining room, and the doors are frequently left open while the toilets are in use. That is not the fault of the mentally ill people who leave them open, but it should not be visible to women.
What can I say in the short time that remains? There is a risk that the pendulum will swing too far. This keeps happening in mental health. At one time, the pendulum swung too far in the direction of institutionalisation: anyone who had anything wrong with them was put away for years—for the better part of their lives, sometimes for ever. That injustice was recognised. Then the pendulum swung the other way, with care in the community, and hardly anyone was admitted as an in-patient.
A compromise has now been reached in distinguishing between those who need to be long-term in-patients and those who can do well in the community. That is good, but I was disturbed to hear the Secretary of State say some time ago in a statement on mental health that community care had failed. No; part of it failed, and part of it succeeded. Now we are trying to get the balance right.
I appeal to the Minister to come out from behind the obfuscation of official language. He cannot have it both ways. Either the Government believe in the principle of single-sex wards, or they believe in the philosophy of a "normalising" environment—in which the single-sex
wards that he is talking about relate only to very basic functions, and there is nowhere for women to be during the day without the intrusion of men. If the Minister's concern is genuine, he must say once and for all tonight that the idea of creating a "normal" environment by putting sick men with sick women, in circumstances in which they cannot be held responsible for their actions, is fatally flawed, is unacceptable, and will finally be rejected.

speech.speakername: The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Health (Mr. John Hutton)
speech.p:
I thank the hon. Member for New Forest, East (Dr. Lewis) for giving me notice of some of the points that he has made. I congratulate him on raising such an important subject tonight. I know that he has a long-standing interest in it: indeed, I believe that he is one of only a few hon. Members to have displayed such a continuing interest. I am grateful to him for giving me the opportunity to set out the Government's intentions in relation to mixed-sex accommodation in psychiatric units.
We should see the issue in the wider context of the Government's plans to modernise mental health services, which we outlined at the end of last year in the strategy document "Modernising Mental Health Services". In that document, we tried to make it clear that we wanted services to be safe, sound and supportive—safe to protect the public, patients and staff, providing effective care for those with mental illness at the time when they need it; sound to ensure that patients are given the best and most appropriate care and treatment in the right settings, and have access to the full range of services; and supportive through work with patients, carers and local communities to help people to lead lives that are as independent as possible.
Effective responses to mental health problems require three elements to be in balance: resources and the systems to make the best use of them, legislative powers, and the processes of care. Deficiencies in one area cannot be compensated for by change in another. Increasing resources—which we are doing—will not be cost-effective unless the necessary care processes are in place; strengthening legislative powers cannot overcome the problems of inadequate resourcing. We recognise that reform in all three areas is needed to modernise mental health services.
Our plans for mental health services, taken with our proposals for modernising health and social care, add up to a comprehensive set of policies that will provide a new vision for mental health services. Our new vision is underpinned by new investment—the hon. Gentleman did not refer to it, but I am sure he will not mind if I do—of £700 million over the next three years. That sum represents the largest single increase in investment in mental health services since the NHS was established in 1948. It will be supported by the development of a new mental health national service framework, which will set new service models, and by a review of the current legislation.
In planning for high-quality mental health and social care, we do not, unfortunately, start with a blank sheet of paper. Instead, we inherit a complex legacy of problems
in policy, planning and the patterns of service delivery. All those need to be addressed. That will take time, but the plans set out in "Modernising Mental Health Services" make clear the direction that we intend to take, with a clear set of objectives and a focus on new investment. "Modernising Mental Health Services" marks a new beginning for mental health provision in England.
On the situation regarding mixed-sex accommodation that we inherited from the previous Administration, it is worth pointing out to the hon. Gentleman, as I know that he has a balanced and sensible approach to these matters, that many of the problems that he rightly identified did not date from 1 May 1997. He will probably want to join me in regretting the fact that the previous Administration, whom he strongly supported, made such poor progress in eliminating mixed-sex accommodation in the NHS.
I am acutely aware of the concerns that have been raised about the safety of patients in psychiatric units. Like the hon. Gentleman, I have had meetings with former patients. I recently met four women who have at various times been patients in the Maudsley hospital. They expressed to me their serious concerns about harassment and serious assaults on acute psychiatric wards. I was extremely concerned by what those women told me of their own experiences. As we have done on previous occasions, I made it clear to them, and I do so again today, that we are committed to getting rid of mixed-sex accommodation in the NHS.
The hon. Gentleman developed his arguments in his comments. It might be helpful to him, and to all the other hon. Members who are present and who are clearly interested in the subject, if we start to define some of our terms. By "single-sex accommodation" we mean clearly defined, separate sleeping areas, separate day rooms and social areas, and separate toilets and washing facilities. Guidance will be issued that will state clearly that male and female toilets and bathing facilities should be located in separate areas, close to respective male and female sleeping areas.
The word "accommodation", about which the hon. Gentleman was concerned, means the whole range of buildings and types of living space used by patients in the NHS. It would be wrong for the hon. Gentleman to suggest that using the word "accommodation" is in any way a narrowing of our manifesto commitment to ensure the safety of women patients who use the NHS. We made a clear promise in our manifesto and we will keep it. I cannot make myself any clearer than that.
I was intrigued by some of the hon. Gentleman's comments. I have read the speech that he made when he introduced his Bill. He might be interested to reflect on some of the words that he used in that debate. Introducing clause 2, he said that it dealt with mixed-sex areas, not wards. He said: I am not talking about big open spaces with male patients at one end of the room and female patients at the other, but all wards should have an area reserved for women if they want that. It would be a refuge room not unlike the ladies waiting rooms provided at some railway stations for women who want to wait in a women-only environment."—[Official Report, 12 December 1997; Vol. 302, c. 1267.] I was rather surprised by the tone of some of the hon. Gentleman's remarks today expressing his concern about the use of the word "accommodation," which I do not think can be justified by what we have said.
I repeat that we will not tolerate violence against women anywhere in the NHS. We are determined that all women in mental health units should be assured of conditions that are safe and free from harassment and abuse. However, we cannot overnight repair the damage of many years' neglect and under-resourcing. The previous Government spoke much about safety, but we are determined to take action to make improvements to protect patients. We inherited a national health service badly in need of modernising, and that is particularly true of mental health services. We also need to bring about a change in culture. Outdated attitudes and practices have no part in the revitalised services that we want to bring about.
What action are we taking? We are taking action on several fronts. We have set the national health service objectives to implement our commitment to the elimination of mixed-sex accommodation. We are monitoring its performance in achieving those objectives and we are to issue further guidance on mixed-sex accommodation. We are investing in staff training and we will ensure that variations across the country are reduced through the implementation of the mental health national service framework, which, in turn, will be monitored and enforced by the Commission for Health Improvement.
I want to say a little more about each of those areas to show that a substantial amount of work is taking place to deliver our commitment to getting rid of mixed-sex accommodation. First, the NHS has been given three key objectives: to ensure that appropriate organisational arrangements are in place to secure good standards of privacy and dignity for all hospital patients; to achieve fully the patients charter standard for segregated washing and toilet facilities across the NHS; and to provide safe facilities for patients in hospital who are mentally ill which safeguard their privacy and their dignity.[Interruption.]
We have made it clear—I say this in response to the sedentary intervention from the hon. Member for Rutland and Melton (Mr. Duncan)—that we expect 95 per cent. of health authorities to have met those objectives by the end of 2002.
Last August, we issued a monitoring tool to ascertain the progress of the NHS towards achieving those objectives. That contained a checklist to assist health authorities in monitoring the processes in place to deliver good physical segregation of the sexes in hospital. It also included additional arrangements for mental health in-patient facilities.
The NHS executive has monitored progress in achieving the objectives that have been laid down and the Government have already published two reports, which show health authorities' progress in this area. A further monitoring report will be published in the spring. We continue to keep this issue high on the NHS agenda, through the performance management systems that we are introducing, and to check hospitals' capital plans to ensure that the money that they have been given contributes towards the elimination of mixed-sex accommodation. As
a clear signal of our commitment in that area, £70 million has been earmarked specifically for that purpose from the NHS capital allocation for next year.
The monitoring checklist produced by the NHS executive included specific points to check that the safety of patients in mental health units is maintained, but we want to go beyond that by producing more detailed guidance that specifically addresses the issues for vulnerable, mentally ill people in hospital. Although there are constraints on the ability of NHS trusts to maintain the best standards in their existing stock of buildings, they must do what they can, within the constraints of the accommodation, to protect patients' privacy and dignity.
We have made it clear that new developments must achieve best practice standards in providing separate accommodation for the sexes. Each of the new schemes is being scrutinised by the regional offices to ensure that they eliminate problems and that they comply fully with the patients charter requirements.
When I addressed a conference of hospital designers and service providers last month, I announced that we would be issuing further guidance for mental health units in the late spring. That guidance will help to inform discussion locally about how to achieve the targets of privacy and dignity. It will also contain examples of good building design and solutions to varying ward layouts and requirements for operational policies that ensure the safety, privacy and dignity of all patients within the NHS.
We want to ensure that trusts have proper management policies in place and protocols to prevent assaults. The guidance will also give advice on what to do, both at trust management level and at individual ward level. It will cover such issues as the assessment of each individual's needs and the risks that they may present; speedy, robust arrangements to deal effectively with staff, or patients, who sexually abuse or harass patients; and monitoring of complaints to enable identification of problems over the care and treatment of women patients.
The guidance will also make it clear that each ward should have a written policy relating to the safety of women and that a designated officer at senior level in the trust should have overall responsibility for the safety of women. I could say more, but we will shortly run out of time.
All those requirements will be reflected in the mental health national service framework, which will specifically address unacceptable variations in services across England. It will set national standards for health and social care and establish performance indicators to measure the progress made by those services.
I can assure the hon. Member for New Forest, East that the NHS will not be complacent about the safety of women. There is no place in the health service for discrimination, sexual harassment or assault—at all. Women must feel safe in mental health services. That is our objective and that is what we will deliver.
